description:
Oil prices are hovering at around $50 a barrel, and it's hard to imagine that only six months ago oil was priced at double that. It's allowed many countries to cut domestic fuel subsidies for consumers, their voters, without too much of a political backlash. Malaysia and Indonesia are just two countries that have been slashing subsidies, subsidies that have guzzled billions of dollars from government coffers over the past decades. In a moment, we'll hear how other countries are also coping. But in the meantime, the World Bank has long advocated abolishing fuel subsidies in developing countries. John Baffes is a senior economist at the bank, so I asked him is it fair to say that fuel subsidies are now globally on the decline.

They are down a little in the last couple of years but they're still high. Just to give you an idea of the orders of money globally, fuel subsidies are in the order of $550 billion per year globally. And they have been going down the last couple of years, but only in the order of $10 or $20 billion, so they're still high more than half a trillion dollars basically.
